children.content: Evaluate for potential cardiovascular causes (History and physical examination, ECG/chest x-ray, Echocardiography, Laboratory testing)
Determine primary anatomic location of dysfunction
RV dysfunction > LV dysfunction: Elevated jugular venous pressure, Ascites, Lower extremity swelling
RV heave, PA tap, Right-sided S3 or S4
Intrinsic RV dysfunction
Acute RV infarction/ischemia
Restrictive cardiomyopathy
Congenital or acquired left-to-right intracardiac shunts
Distant heart sounds, knock, rub
Pericardial disease: Tamponade constriction
RV dysfunction secondary to pulmonary hypertension
Cor pulmonale: Thromboembolic disease, PPH, Pulmonic stenosis, Connective tissue diseases, HIV, Medications
LV dysfunction > RV dysfunction: Rales, Crackles
Normal PMI, S4
LVEF normal
Increased LV afterload: Systemic hypertension, Aortic coarctation, Renal artery stenosis
Diastolic dysfunction: Acute ischemia, LV hypertrophy (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or secondary to hypertension, diabetes mellitus, aortic stenosis), Restrictive cardiomyopathy
Diffuse/lateral PMI, S3
LVEF decreased
Primary myocardial dysfunction: Prior myocardial infarction, Diffuse cardiomyopathy
Murmur
Valvular disease: Aortic stenosis/insufficiency, Mitral stenosis/regurgitation
Consider noncardiovascular causes of dyspnea: Pulmonary, Neurologic, Musculoskeletal
